titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxv — no.3 Richmond, Va. Friday, July 3, 1863 Price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

Arthur F. Boreman, Governor J. D. Royce, of State Auditor.
B Caldwell, Attorney General William A. Harrison and James H Brown, Judges of the Supreme Court of Appeals, Albert H. Caldwell, Judge of the First Circuit, John Lille, Judge of the Second Circuit, Thomas W. Harrison, Judge of the Third Circuit, Caspian J. Stuart, Judge of the Fourth Circuit, George Judge of the Sixth Circuit, Daniel Paisley, Judge of the Seventh Circuit, Henry J. Samuel Judge of the Eighth Circuit, and John W. Kennedy, Judge of the Tenth Circuit, and a vacancy in the Ninth Circuit.

div3.head: Gen. Lee's army.
div3.p: An officer who came down to the Central gives a glowing of the march of the army through the lower Valley of Virginia to Maryland where they were greeted by the people as deliverers, and every upon the of the people would

The officer says that the amount of supplies and the number of Virginia and Maryland throughout and Winchester on the route to the upper Valley, and long trains of wagons were crossing the Potomac, making their way southward with their supplies.

div3.head: The last fight at Vicksburg
div3.p:
Capt. M, Counell, who came out of Vicksburg, on the 17th, after the falls on Saturday . The enemy were badly whipped, in their assault, and there is a plenty of ammunition in the ally to meet other assaults.
The the casualties at Vicksburg as for as he could learn from friends and of his own

Capt Thos. Emanuel, Mobile, Capt. McRae Major Halley, of a Tennessee regiment, killed; Col.Russell, of the wounded, Col. Marise, of La., very seriously wounded, Col. Pallen, of N. C., Col. Glenn, of La., Col. McCron II.
and Col. Harris, of Louisiana, killed.
Captain of Memphis Battery, wounded, Colonel Herrick was killed.--He had that morning received his nomination as Colonel, went out as commander for the and was .

for Gen. Pemberton, who is at all of this day and night on duty of the at the front the write or at his office attending in business.
He and his gallant staff are on all the whole garrison has the continued in their ability to hold the city any odds.

When he left there were at least sixty days provisions, and they were . There was also plenty of water.
The of starving the army was considered as the .

div3.head: Matters in the North.
div3.p:
Some of the prisoner recently returned by flag of truce both from the North represent of the state of the and at the North upon the invasion of Pennsylvania without an opportunity to the prevailing excitements.
Two returned prisoners of Gen. James's cavalry brigade, captured in the Valley, yesterday informed us that in addition to the regular guard for the cannon in Fort McHenry, heavy details were slightly to sleep by the to be prepared for his which he apprehended from the of the South, in Baltimore, Every of approach to the city strongly and hogs-heads of tobacco have been in brighter.

div3.head: The capture of the U. S. Cushing.
div3.p:
Lieut Chas. Wediend. C.S.N., who destiny of the Cushing at Portland, Saturday, and who lately commanded the Tacony, is a native of Reverend Ms.
He entered the U. S. Naval Academy in and graduated with honor in 1860.
After the wounding of the lament Huger the Maltes at New Orleans.
Lieut. Read, being the Executive officer command and gallantly fought the vessel.
He was slap on the Arkansas memorable engagement with the Yankee Mississippi floor and bore a His in the Florida from Mobile, and according to Northern papers who given command of the tender to the Florida, with which be captured the Tacony.
She bring a he turned present the crew to her.

a paper of the 28th mention the occupation of York Pa., by the Confederate trued.
They entered the place Saturday at afternoon about 5 o'clock. The two represents of Col., Thomas and Frick A dispatch from Harrisburg, dated the of the says:

q.p:
At o'clock to day a skirmish took place at Gap. Eleven miles from where the Pennsylvania ere as the river.
[There is the where from Philadelphia to Harrisburg]. we had four killed in the Nashville's Gap. eighteen miles from Harrisburg:

div3.p:
The people from all parts of the State are promptly responding to the Governor's proclamation of yesterday.
The excitement here . The streets are crowded with citizens and strangers who are issuing out by the city.
The greatest has and feeling to do all he can to assist in the State and country.

Adj. Gen. Russell issued on order this afternoon that be given to all citizens on application at the Arsenal, When at best 3,000 made application for weapons.
of the men who bid or as were companies and marched across this river.

Harrisburg, June 27th Midnight --Information has been received the Confederate force which at 4 o'clock this afternoon, has arrived in front of the junctions of the and In that event the Pennsylvania Central will be cut.

div4.head: The
div4.p: A Washington telegram of the 21th says:

q.p: The rebel authorities still decline do exchange of either officers and civilians who fall into their hands, we may be of exchanged of of prisoners, as well as progress, and to he will be transportation will be provided.

div4.head: The last arrivals at Fort Lafayette--Distinguished rebels.
div4.p: Under this head the N. Y. announces twenty four arrivals at Fort Lafayette, some of the prisoners being thinks, to devote separate paragraphs to — it says:

q.p:
Among them to be noted Thomas Launders, who was an officer in the rebel service and one of the spills in the attack upon the Hirriel Lane.
After the capture of the Hirriel was placed in command of her, but, none active service the position and place

Alfred Brownwell is a prisoner of some importance from the he had been alerted by the Secretary of the Rebel to proceed to New York and ink, paper, pistol, and all for rebel Brownwell was clerk in the rebel Treasury Department, and understood precisely what was required.
He arrived in New York made very extensive purchases, and had arrived very near by the United States and the entire to the Brownwell has been a of Europe on several occasions for the rebels cities the breaking out of the war, and has rendered all the aid and comfort to the enemy possible.
It will be to his friends to know that he is in Fort Lafayette.

John T. is the only other prisoner of importance, if we may except Edward Dexter, who was by a military commission by Gen. div4.head: The at the North.
div4.p: The New York world, of the 25th alt., has the subject of the "Apathy which a at the North, relative to the approach of Gen. Lee's force." It says:

q.p:
The Northern people do not rise as who back the legions of Lee beyond the they have their face in the Government against, which those legions are moving and which has and machinery of defence.
The Northern people to the apprehension of the Northern people the war for the for the House of the Union in the apprehension of the this mighty conflict and the of the of a and schemers, who neither which fired the Northern heart of the Northern people in waging their additional war Under the the laws the people are powerless to the of their own affairs, through the and repulsive of

div4.p:
These they have not yet been these they carefully hope and desire that they may not be employing.
They know that we have still in the field which properly and properly at least, for the of the North, or they cannot rescue the subjugation of the South.
These armies are subject to the cruelty of the Federal Government.
The Federal Government is responsible for them and for the work they are told.
Did the Government possess the confidants and command the sympathies of these people, this in to attract the of their and their passion today.
But the Government the confidence, it has of the Northern people, and new, in this crisis of we ought surprised however we may be grieved to said the Government left in with the solemn emergency of the if the Administrator, which has disappointed so many legitimate hopes, which has wasted now fulfill the single first duty of a Government if it armies and all its of an armed occupation, it is that we should look thinks fully in the face and know precisely what we have to anticipate in the future.--The spirit, the energy, the devotion of the people, have long enough given to incapacity and selfishness and blindest fully the "ample and verge enough, they need Sooner or the army of ascertain whether it is is not by and accept the of the discovery.
There can be not better time then the present to learn the truth, be it over so batter or full of peril.

This, we say, is to us the direct and rational explanation of a popular apathy which it were other wise impossible to comprehend.
It is the apathy not of despair, but of disgust; the agony of men awaiting a crucial experiment, had not at mankind to the experiment.
We have send the Administration at work for two years in the talk of aggression and assertion, and the carried disappointment and desolation through . We it now dealing for its with aggression and with assertion, with armies which it has had the means the responsibility a hundred over of demons king, and with an organized power which, it has sedulously belittled both to ourselves and to the world.

The people are weary of its words, they leave it now to the test of its works.
By that test it will assuredly or fall, for the enemies it has to do with now are men who do not their work negligently.
And should to fall beneath the dread ordeal, the apathy which it 16 day to the trial will be followed of which the memory, be sure, will travel on ward and down ward to the remotest peace of men.

div3.head: Beat Butler at the Charleston Convention.
div3.p: --A correspondent of the Mobile gives that paper an inside at in Botler's while a member of the Charleston Democratic Convention.

It is well known that this infamous Yankees was a member of the Charleston Convention, assembled to nominate a President, but it is not generally known that he was there in a committee room by three gentlemen, members of the committee to that resolutions, & c. The names of the members who him were Mr. Smith of California, (a active of Virginia.) Mr. of Miss., and Mr., now Governor of Texas, Butler, in course of his and course remark in was by Smith which he took like a dog. Mr. Labboak took him in hand, and cover the him with words, and would his face if he had not and been suddenly taken with the soldiers.
Mr. Barksdale, was compared to notice the of the Yankee, and would have broken his head with a which he of for the purpose, but for the having white and the experted blew.--A member of the committee, present, says that such cowardice war almost inconceivable and that it was to look at him while he was under the apprehension of being under.

div3.head: The casualties at Knoxville,
div3.p: -- A correspondent of the Continue ga Rebel, writing from Knoxville about the attack on that place says:

q.p:
During the action Mrs. Trezevant, lady of Capt. Trezevant of New who was temporarily in Knoxville, received a wound in the right soldier, from the fragment of a fired by the enemy.--A lady, whose two little children were playing about the garden with the choose of their age, rant out immediately to bring them into the house when a shell from the enemy's battery exploded in the of the innocent grasp and killed all She had but just gathered one of them in her arms and was in the act of reaching over her head to grasp the other.
Capt. McClang, who was killed, had both legs torn away by a shell, and only one of the mangled limbs was afterwards found.

div3.head: Valuable trunk lost.
div3.p: --The Augusta (Ga) Constitutionalist has the following word story lady traveler:

q.p: A lady took passage on one of the outgoing train of a railroad not a hundred miles from this city, and overlooked a small trunk, which on receptacle of appeared the in the railroad agent, exchange a bill for --the value at which she as

div3.p: was made, however, and was found, and & It was removed to its rightful owner, who the railroad agent store and that it was all right and just as she had

The following we are assured is the sum and substance of the contents of that valuable . We give the list of articles at the by the railroad agent, and, also, at such price at would being the value by It is to be hoped that the prominence example by of cut deplore in the arise of life has out spread to the portion of creation, and it is in the there was no of extortion but rather an error in setting down the figure.
But here is the

div3.head: Yankee raiders drowned.
div3.p: --The Knoxville (Tenn.) Register has the following paragraph:

q.p:
At the Federal raiders came into Part Tennessee, in farding at Esquire Montgomery a on Church river, some fifteen of them were drowned.
No was made by the Yankees to look after their commands Five of the bodies were recovered from the river and by our soldiers and loyal citizens.

div3.head: A Yankee
div3.p: --A writing about Vicksburg, tells the following Yankee trick:

q.p:
There of a real Yankee trick to get provisions past our batteries, but our boys were too sharp for them.
They had to had barrels of pork to of logs and

div3.head: The last of them.
div3.p:
--The has disappeared from the British Pollament.
Daniel of the and lately member for Trades, in the county of Kerry, has been off by the having been appointed a special of the At only member of the House of Commons the family.
The following annual have been granted in the English civilian.-- Francis Browne. £400, on annual of her works in composed in spite of blindness existing from birth.

A dispatch published to the New York paper of the Shelbyville had been occupied by the Federal troops.
This advance on the part of Rosecrane:

q.p: John McDonnoll, the proprietor of the famous McDonnoll's restaurant, New Orleans, died on the of May last.

div3.p: Garibaldi still walks with a crutch; but his health is sensibly improving.
Flour is $75 a barrel in Mississippi.

-- Saturday night and Tuesday morning the family of Mr. E. W. Tompkins, on Broad near was entered and robbed of between 2,000 of Grand 3,000 worth of groceries.--The burglar effected an entranced by pouring through Mr. Ratcliffe's lot climbing the division fence, then boring through Mr. T.'s bark door.
The groceries taken were, tea, bacon, sugar, soap, lard and beans.
Owing to the death of Mr. T's mother, the were was not opened from Saturday night till Tuesday the robbery was discovered in the latter On Tuesday, a negro fellow catered mr. Mark Downey's store and offered to sell a bag of tea, stating that he brought it from General McD, respecting this negro very closely and hastily made him suffers that he proceed the tea in this city.
the negro admitted that he received the tea of William Stephen.
Clara of H. H. Miller, who keeps a cook shop to Pink Alley, and who give it to him to sell.
This negro was taken from castled and Mr. Tompkins apprised of all the facts.

Mr. Tompkins next procured a search warrant, and placing it in Policeman Kelly's place bad it executed.
That officer, a here, searched William's cook and there fined a small quantity of the fourteen pounds of sugar, and a small beg of beans, similar to those lost by Mr. Tompkins.
On being blame by questioned, William admitted that he gave the bag of tea to the negro to sell, and that he is offered it of Gerard, a slave.
The officers then followed Gerard to his wife's house, where they recovered some sugar and other a trunk fall of groceries, which he threw into an adjoining lot, and which were found there in morning.
Gerard than that he received the goods of Dick, and left them with William Stephens — that the burglary was committed at night, and that another negro named Charles, the deliver of an ambulance, handed the goods away.
Gerard further stated that Dick had told the lard and to George S. Sarzon's grocer on Broad street, and the bacon and sugar to Josiah L. Mosby, another grocer.

To ascertain the truth of Gerard's statement, Search warrants were proceed, and the houses of Stung and Mosby examined.
In that of Sarzon's quantity of lard and soap were found, which Mr. Tompkins believed to be his, and which Mrs. Tomkins believed to be his, and which Mrs. to haying purchased of Deck, in the absence of her husband.
In Mosby and been were found, as which Mr. Tompkins believed to be . [Mosby proved by his son and daughter that he had bad the and bacon for month]. his wife and Mosby were then arrested.
Officers next proceeded to arrest Dick, and succeeded, but not on if he had a young man who a tempted stop him, and had been
All the above facts, the Mayor adjourned the investigating the Saturday, in order to ascertain the value of the stolen.

div3.head: Stealing clothes.
div3.p:
--French Foushee, a young man apparently years of age, his appearance before the Mayor yesterday to answer the charge of stealing a quantity of military clothing, supposed to be the property of a Maryland company.
Officer found the in the Blakey, and was informed that were there by the . On Wednesday officer knowing anything of the Blakey proved by his son that brought the them sold.
After person had taken charge of the goods to get them, saying that he could roll the caps of. (The clothes are now believed to be the property of the Washington Artillery) Blanket believed the goods to prisoner, as no one else had ever claimed them.
Pending the relative to the clothes, Mr. L. A. Writing was to the that in the latter part of May to work in the point shop with him. On Thursday box where the in the shop only knew

div3.p:
--Owing to the excitement in the Court-room the Mayor his Court before Kearney, knife and John Murphy — Patrick Burdes and his wife Mary, for entering the of David off the roof.
George William on, John Riley, David Sinker, and Edward J. Williams, stealing a watch and of Wm G.

div3.head: Felonious shooting.
div3.p: James charged with shooting with intent to on the night of the of May, while in the discharge of his duty, Watchman John Troner, was examined and remanded to the Hustings Court for a her

div3.head: Drowned.
div3.p: --Yesterday morning George W. nine years of the son of Mrs. Mary A. Walls, was drowned while in the Black on Union His had com away from the paid, leaving him there, before body in it quire dead.

Bath Rooms are springing upon almost every neighborhood in the city, and, as a consequence, intemperance soldiers one increase.
The Secretary of War appealed in the Hasting Court, and the Council to aid in the suppression of thinking for the good of the army, and the Mayor was ready to rend the influence of his police in the work of suppressing unlawful but turning a deaf ear to this appeal, the Court has granted licenses by the range, and the consequence is, that nearly every neighborhood in the heart of the city has one or more bathrooms in full blast.
On Tuesday night last three or four were arrested and caged by the city police, for being drunk in the streets, and yesterday morning the Recorder turned them over to there officers and the Provost Marshal.
If of officers call loonies, the military authorities will be compelled to adopt plan for the on of the soldiers against the

The Militia, prompt to the call of the authorities, printed out on yesterday, and were ready to defend the batteries and their of every hazard.
When the call was made there was no silly excitement, but every men, cool as a regular buckled on his turn sack, shouldered the muskets, and was ready and or for the fray.

div3.head: Theft Caught.
div3.p: --William, a slave of Mr. Sweeney, was charged in the while stealing from J. Hastings.
--James charged with island without have a hearing the Model on

div3.head: From the Southwest.
div3.p: Jackson, Miss, July, -- two was on the a few days since.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--Northing whatever from the front to day. Brick firing is going on at Vicksburg.
Forty- one negro soldiers, captured by Lyons near Port Hudson, arrived here this evening.
They say they were forced to take up arms.

div4.head: [Third Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--[Special to the Mississippian.]--, 1st--The New Orleans Eve, of the 25th, says Col. Ellis, of Gen. Monilen's command, capture two batteries at Bayon Derallemands.
The 2nd Connecticut regiment, to their relief were also captured.
Advices from New Orleans, to the 19 party the Confederates made a raid into A'glers and destroyed all the Government slaves, also captured a on the Railroad, and Bayon Derallemands.
The Mississippian also an authentic source that Price undoubtedly occupies

div3.p:
--The bill relative to the collection of taxes and funding certain issue passed the Legislature to day. It requires and collectors to receive all General of Confederate treasury notes writing the Treasurer to fund all in notes before the 25th of July in 7 per cent. Confederate bonds, and sell the same at pay or for a premium, or to pay the of the State to parties willing to receive them.
After the 1st of August all issues are to be received without declination, as heretofore.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
The will reward will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me, or delivery in that I may get them, of my two negro men, Jordon and Sam, who left on friday night the 28th of June.
Jordon has right foot in the head is about 35 years of age, Sam about 27.
Jordon was purchased from was county, Va., Sam from North Carolina.
They may try to make their way back.
The above reward will be paid for their delivery to me.
div3.closer:
Wm. H. Wilkinson,
Powhatan Va. jy--3t*

div3.head: Runaway--$200 reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber, on the morning of the 18th of 1863, my Negro Boy Ben, he is about years of age, of a dark gingerbread complexion, about 5 feet 3 inches in height.
He had on when he left a light colored jacket, a pair of blue Yankee pants and a blue hat; and he is trying to make his way his way to the Yankee.
I will pay the above reward if delivered to me, or one hundred and fifty dollars if secured in any jail so that I may him. Post Office, Richmond.
div3.closer:
Sarah Sydeor,
of W. B. Sydeor Va.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p:
--from the subscriber, on the night of the 19th of June, my negro boy Walker, about five feet high, brown complexion, full head of hair, rather stout built; and and Said boy was bought in this city on the 24th of June.
He was the with the Valley of Virginia owned by the Smith, of the above county.
I will give fifty dollars for his to me, or if placed in any place where I can get him.

div3.head: Runaway--$200REWARD.
div3.p:
--Runaway, on the inst, my man William.
He is about 28 years old, 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, frame, gingerbread color, and is the city at Wm Tinsley.

left my place about 6 o'clock yesterday morning.
is about 35 years old, and likely about 23 years old, gingerbread color, and well
I will pay three hundred dollars for the delivery of or one hundred dollars for

div3.head: Runaway--$100 reward.
div3.p: --Run away from the subscriber last night, a negro boy named Martin, purchased of Dr. M A of He is about 5 feet 5 or 6 inches in height, stout built, and good teeth about 20 years old. He was making his way toward Louisiana reward if delivered to James, of Richmond, or if confined in jail

Three hundred dollars reward will be paid for the apprehension and return to me, in jail on that named Alfred and Penny Va. on the night of the all their 45 years of age, good teeth they are supposed to be their way to Ports left my house on the 2d day of June, is about 5 two inches high, dark complexion, very short legs, and long for his height; and is about years of age. When last heard from was about eight miles beyond county, Va. and will probably way to The above reward will be paid for the delivery of the three negroes or each.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p: -- reward, will be paid for the apprehension of Jim for Ran away from Jim is about 5 feet or 8 inches high, of brown color, stout built,

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p: --Will be paid for the apprehension of Jesse, Jesse is about 17 years of age and medium built, very black, has pleasant is slightly The above reward of $50 will be paid for his delivery to me.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber, the 13th of May, my negro man The said negro and formerly and Main streets.
He left the properties of Mr. where his wife lives.
from to town in Lynchburg.
I will give the above reward for his delivery at any jail, so that I may get him again.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 25, Number 3, page 2.

div3.head: Married.
div3.p: On Tuesday, the 23d at the residence of the father, in county, by the Rev Richard H Harris of Culpeper, and daughter of John H. Doggolt, formerly of Va.

div4.p: Suddenly on the morning of the 2d inst, at the residence of Mrs Minter, Mrs Mary W in the 25th year of her age.
Her funeral will take places from the Grace Street Baptist Church, (Dr. Jetere) this morning, at 11 o'clock. Her friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend without further notice.
On the inst, of whooping cough Laura Ellen, daughter of Geo W and Belle Norman, aged 7 months and 9 days.
Her funeral will take place from the Trinity Church it is afternoon at 5 o'clock. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend. *
Suddenly, from drowning on the 1st inst, Geo W Walle, in the 9th years of his age, son of Mrs Mary A and the late John Walls.
His funeral will take place from his mother's residence on Venable street, Union Hill, this afternoon at 4 o'clock. The friends of the family are requested to attend without further notice. *
On the 2d inst, of consumption, Archibald E. Miller in the 27th year of his age, leaving a wife and one child to mourn their loss. *
Lynchburg papers please copy. *

div3.head: Substitutes Wanted.
div3.p:
--The subscriber wishes to employ two Substitutes--one for infantry and the other for cavalry.
The highest price will be paid for two reliable men. Call to day, from 9 to 12 o'clock, at A Y Stokes & Co's.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted
div3.p:
--Wanted, a substitute to go in any company he may desire.
For a good men, over forty five years of age, thirty five hundred dollars will be paid.
Apply at the "Columbian" for two days.

div3.head: Substitute
div3.p: -- on Alex H Goodman, of Cartarsville county, Va.

div3.head: Substitute.
div3.p: --Any person wishing a Substitute can get one by calling, on Henry Miller, Cary street, opposite Talbott's Foundry.

div3.head: Negroes to Hire and Stable for rent
div3.p:
--An excellent Cook and Washer and a Boy, 9 years old to waiting on the table.
Also, for rent, a Stable reliable for two horses and a with provender from attached.
Apply to office of 1st Auditor of Treasurer Department.

div3.head: Attention 6th Company, 17th Regiment
div3.p: --company will report to me this morning in front of the City Hall, on Broad street at 8 o'clock. Every man between the age of 18 and 40 in the following North by by 17th street, South by the river, and West by 20th street.

div3.head: Attention, Letcher mounted guard
div3.p: --Meet in front of the city this (Friday) afternoon at 5 o'clock. Meeting will mounted.
div3.closer:
By order D. M. Lea,Capt.
G. Stores. C. S. jy 3--1t*

div3.head: The Letcher mounted
div3.p: --This Company, which has for the of the city, will receive a few more men, who will apply to day at the of William &

div3.head: Notice
div3.p:
--I am authorized by Col. D J to re company of cavalry for his commend to operate in this victory.
and equipments furnished.
All who wish to join will apply at my office in the State Court House, our of 12th

div3.head: Attention Militia.
div3.p:
--The 4th Company of the 179th, Regiment Virginia Militia will must for drill every Evening, at o'clock, on the corner of Ross and 14th streets. This call all men not actually enrolled and into the Confederate between the age of 18 and years.
Sleeping in the bounds of this wit: between 12th and 14th streets and Broad street and the river.
div3.closer:
By order,
J. M. Macon Jr.
Capt. 4th 128th Regiment. jy --3t*

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p: --All French and meet at on 7th street every-day, at 4 P M, to form into for the defence of the city.--Their prompt attention
-- reward will be paid for the and confinement of the following from my company:
Hugh Murphy, a substitute aged 48 years, light blue eyes, sandy hair, florid complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high; born in Ireland, occupation, laborer.
Timothy Serman, a substitute, aged 46 years, dark eyes, black hair, sprinkled with gray, dark complexion, 5 feet 5 inches high, born in Ireland; occupation, laborer.
div3.closer:
Capt. Light
Camp Alexandria
Richmond, June 22d, je

div3.head: Attention Marilanders.
div3.p:
--Every consideration of pride and interest to unite for the redemption of your native State.
An opportunity now offers to entires favorable branch of the service, with many substitute advantage and under your own banner.
A Cavalry Company is being formed to join the 1st Harvard Cavalry, under command of Major Ridgley Brown Horses and equipments furnished immediately and active service entered without delay.
Those serving in regiments from other States can be transferred and to those wishing to enter the services a better opportunity can hardly occur.
For further particulars apply at the Rough and Ready Saloon; on Main street between 8th and 9th streets.

div3.head: Deserters--reward.
div3.p: --I will pay the above reward for the apprehension of each or either of the following named deserters:
N Kneoughty, 8 years old 5 feet 6 inches high, complexion, dark hair and eyes, deserted June 19th, 1863.
W Kneoughty, 30 years of age, 5 feet 10 inches high, complexion, light hair and blue eyes June 23d, 1863.
M Kneoughty, years of age 6 feet high, fair complexion, dark hair and eyes, June 23d, 1863.
R Breeder, 25 years of age 6 feet 2 inches high, fair complexion, light hair and blue eyes; June 23d, 1863.
The above men are from Va.
div3.closer:
E. R. Young,
Capt. on je 2d--2t*

div3.head:
[Extract]
Adj't and Inst'r Genl's office.
Richmond, June 22,
div3.p:
Special Orders.
No. 118.--

XXI. Lieut. Col Rugene E Q M General C S A the general of inspection of the Department, in the various of the service throughout the army.
He will immediately enter upon the duties of his office and will make his reports of Inspection to this office through the General.
div3.closer:
By command of the of War.
John Withers.
Assistant Gen'l. je 2d--6t

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I offer a reward of for the apprehension and delivery to me at No. 7, Richmond of John Lavin a private and army company.
Said 5 feet high, has blue eyes, and light complexion, and is from on the night of the 2d June.
In addition to the Government reward of will pay for his apprehension

[Extract.]
Adj't and Genl's office.
Richmond, June 22, 1863.
Richmond May 5, 1863.

XXIII.
The now in Petersburg who have lately been in will proceed to rejoin their proper as they shall have been

By command of the Secretary of War John Witheer,
Assistant Adjutant General. my 5--ts

div3.head: Notice--$230 reward
div3.p: --Deserted from 10th Va on the 17th of August, Thomas Lewis Said 5 feet 8 inches high, dark complexion, gray eyes, dark hair and about 25 years of age. He was from county, Va, in May, has been seen there by I will give the usual reward of $20 for his apprehension.

on the 17th February 1863.
